speaker: Rob
text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we introduce a refreshing topic and six related items of vocabulary. I'm Rob.

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m Neil… And today we’re talking about water – there’s nothing more refreshing than an ice-cold bottle of water straight out of the vending machine… Ah!

speaker: Refreshing  Refreshing
text: OK. Refreshing in this context means making you feel cool again after being hot. So has that cooled you down, Neil?

speaker: Neil
text: Yes, I feel very refreshed now, thanks.

speaker: Rob
text: Can I ask you though – why didn’t you just get a glass of water from the kitchen tap? That water is cool and refreshing too – and it’s free!

speaker: Enriched
text: Well, I like this brand of bottled water better – it’s enriched with salts and minerals that are very beneficial to your health. Enriched means improving the quality of something by adding to it.

speaker: Rob
text: Enriched!! Honestly, Neil!

speaker: Neil
text: It tastes better, Rob.

speaker: Rob
text: Yeah…

speaker: Neil
text: And I’m not the only one who thinks so. For the first time in the UK, bottled water is more popular than cola. In fact, can you tell me how many litres of bottled water were sold in the UK in 2016? Was it…

speaker: Neil
text: a) 2.9 billion litres,

speaker: Neil
text: b) 29 million litres or

speaker: Neil
text: c) 2.9 million litres?

speaker: Rob
text: Right. Well, I’m going to say 29 million litres.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. We’ll find out later if you got that right or wrong. But seriously, Rob, don’t you think it’s a good thing that people are choosing to buy bottled water at the supermarket rather than fizzy drinks?

speaker: Rob
text: Yes, of course. But as I said to you earlier, why don’t people just drink tap water? Let’s listen to Natalie Fee, founder of City to Sea, which campaigns against plastic pollution – and of course, bottled water causes a huge amount of that. Here’s Natalie now, talking about how drinks manufacturers have persuaded people that bottled water is better for them.

speaker: Natalie Fee, founder of City to Sea
text: They manufactured the demand for bottled water and they spent millions of pounds on adverts sort of scaring us off of tap water. The bottled water companies set out to make us believe that tap water wasn’t healthy. And yet, tap water is way more regulated than bottled water is, and in taste tests, tap water comes up trumps most times.

speaker: manufacture
text: If you manufacture something you make it in large amounts in a factory. But here Natalie says the drinks companies ‘manufactured the demand for bottled water’…

speaker: Rob
text: Which means they made adverts to persuade people that tap water wasn’t healthy – and bottled water was.

speaker: Neil
text: Hmm – To scare people off – What does that mean, Rob?

speaker: scare somebody off
text: Well, if you scare somebody off you make them go away by frightening them. So some advertisers may have suggested, for example, that tap water was unsafe to drink …

speaker: Neil
text: Whereas bottled water was safer, and tasted better too!

speaker: Rob
text: You’re catching on! However, Natalie Fee claims that tap water is more regulated than bottled water is.

speaker: Neil
text: Regulated means controlled. Natalie also says that in taste tests tap water comes up trumps. What does she mean by that?

speaker: comes up trumps
text: Well, a taste test is where you ask people to try several very similar products without knowing which one is which, and then you grade them according to which you like the best. And if something comes up trumps – it means it produces a good result, often unexpectedly.

speaker: Neil
text: So tap water comes up trumps, eh?

speaker: Rob
text: Yup. Perhaps you should try a taste test now, Neil? It would be interesting to see if your enriched bottled water comes up trumps of not!

speaker: Neil
text: I tell you what, let’s leave that until later and hear the answer to today’s quiz question instead.

speaker: Rob
text: OK.

speaker: Neil
text: I asked you: How many litres of bottled water were sold in the UK in 2016? Was it… a) 2.9 billion litres, b) 29 million litres or c) 2.9 million litres?

speaker: Rob
text: Yeah. And I said 29 million litres.

speaker: Neil
text: And the answer is… 2.9 billion litres.

speaker: Rob
text: Wow!

speaker: Neil
text: You can buy many different brands of bottled water with a range of price tags. At the top end, there’s water from a 4,000 year-old Norwegian iceberg.

speaker: Rob
text: How much does that cost?

speaker: Neil
text: Around £80 a bottle.

speaker: Rob
text: As cheap as that? I’ll pop out and get some later. OK let’s review the words we learned today. The first one was ‘refreshing’, which means making you feel cool again after being hot.

speaker: Neil
text: “I enjoyed a refreshing cup of tea.”

speaker: Rob
text: We British like to say that, don’t we? Though I don’t understand how a hot drink can be refreshing. OK – number two – ‘enriched’, which means improving the quality of something by adding to it. For example, “Did you know that many types of breakfast cereal are enriched with vitamins and minerals, Neil?”

speaker: Neil
text: No, I didn’t, Rob. You learn something new every day. Number three is ‘manufacture’ – to make something in large amounts in a factory. “This company manufactures wellington boots.”

speaker: Rob
text: “I am a wellington boot manufacturer.” That has a nice ring to it. Anyway, when you scare someone off you make them go away by frightening them. “The dog barked fiercely and scared off the two burglars.”

speaker: Neil
text: Down, Rob, down! Number five – ‘regulated’ – or controlled – for example, “The sale of tobacco is tightly regulated by the government.”

speaker: Rob
text: And finally – if something ‘comes up trumps’ it produces a good result, often unexpectedly.

speaker: Neil
text: “My lottery ticket came up trumps again! I can’t believe it!”

speaker: Rob
text: You’re a lucky man, Neil. OK – it’s time to do that taste test now. If you have an opinion on bottled water or anything else, please tell us about it on our Twitter, Instagram, Facebook, or YouTube pages.

speaker: Neil
text: OK. This one definitely tastes better.

speaker: Rob
text: And how about this one?

speaker: Neil
text: Yeah, definitely.

speaker: Rob
text: That’s the tap water, Neil.

speaker: Neil
text: No, no, no. I refuse to believe it!
